body: May this message be a blessing to you if you have ears to hear.
body_html: May this message be a blessing to you if you have ears to hear.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: From my limited understanding it's because of the scholarship behind the translations. Non Majority Text/Texts Receptus have had more liberal/secular scholarship such as Westcott, Hort, and Aland.
body_html: From my limited understanding it's because of the scholarship behind the translations. Non Majority Text/Texts Receptus have had more liberal/secular scholarship such as Westcott, Hort, and Aland.

body:
But the Textus Receptus didn't exist until the 16th century with Erasmus. And the Majority Text is a later branch of the original that became popular in the Eastern Orthodox churches.

And the new translations are anything but liberal scholarship. All of them refuse to select variants that are no longer extant in the rather late Greek manuscripts we have in our possession today. Even when it's painfully obvious that the original was different, an example being 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 not belonging in the text, they will only go with available Greek manuscript variants.
body_html:
But the Textus Receptus didn't exist until the 16th century with Erasmus. And the Majority Text is a later branch of the original that became popular in the Eastern Orthodox churches.

And the new translations are anything but liberal scholarship. All of them refuse to select variants that are no longer extant in the rather late Greek manuscripts we have in our possession today. Even when it's painfully obvious that the original was different, an example being 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 not belonging in the text, they will only go with available Greek manuscript variants.

body:
Westcott and Hort heavily dealt with the occult and Kurt Aland doesn't believe in the canonicity of the Bible. 

The other is that either Codex Sinaitcus or Vaticanus is a forgery and both are corrupted.

I'm still researching these so I've not come to a conclusion on this.

I'm still researching these so I've not come to a conclusion on this.

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
> Westcott and Hort heavily dealt with the occult

Lots of Christians used to be involved in occult antics, more examples being the Salem witch trials and medieval obsession with magic and slaying dragons. It sounds abhorrent today but these things were much more commonplace and tempting back then. In any case as I said they do not make editorial changes, they merely select the extant Greek variant which is most likely to be the original. Usually this is something like the order of a few words.

> Kurt Aland doesn't believe in the canonicity of the Bible

Unless you're Catholic or Orthodox there's no reason for you to either.

> The other is that either Codex Sinaitcus or Vaticanus is a forgery and both are corrupted.

They are corrupt, but the majority text is later and even more corrupt. All NT references in the first few centuries reference pre-Alexandrian texts, nothing Byzantine. Even though some quote Byzantine interpolations such as Mark 16:9-20, that just means that passage was added before the Byzantine text took shape and easily existed in the earlier text type back then.
body_html:
Westcott and Hort heavily dealt with the occult

Lots of Christians used to be involved in occult antics, more examples being the Salem witch trials and medieval obsession with magic and slaying dragons. It sounds abhorrent today but these things were much more commonplace and tempting back then. In any case as I said they do not make editorial changes, they merely select the extant Greek variant which is most likely to be the original. Usually this is something like the order of a few words.

Kurt Aland doesn't believe in the canonicity of the Bible

Unless you're Catholic or Orthodox there's no reason for you to either.

The other is that either Codex Sinaitcus or Vaticanus is a forgery and both are corrupted.

They are corrupt, but the majority text is later and even more corrupt. All NT references in the first few centuries reference pre-Alexandrian texts, nothing Byzantine. Even though some quote Byzantine interpolations such as Mark 16:9-20, that just means that passage was added before the Byzantine text took shape and easily existed in the earlier text type back then.
